III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Alternatives for Girls is a newly constructed facility located near the downtown area of
Detroit. The facility has two floors. The first floor consists of the following: lobby and
reception area; counseling rooms; library; parenting center; classrooms; large
multipurpose room; conference room; office space; storage space; fireproof file room;
office supplies/equipment; employee center and kitchen area; restrooms; and
mechanical rooms that house the individual heating and cooling equipment.
There is a garage adjacent to the first floor. There is a fence around the entire building
and a large parking lot in the enclosed area.
The sleeping areas are on the second floor. There are 14 bedrooms that accommodate
2 residents in each room. A bathroom is connected between every two rooms. There is
one handicapped accessible bedroom and a handicapped accessible bathroom. All of
the rooms have new beds, linen, and dressers. There are also 5 family suites on this
floor. Each room accommodates one resident and up to two children. There are
bathrooms adjoining each room. Minors who are living in the facility will be maintained
in a corridor of rooms that is separate from residents who are over 18 years of age.
The second floor also includes the following: counseling room; activity/recreation room;
arts and crafts room; children’s play room; kitchen area/dining room ; laundry room; pay
phones and emergency phones; storage areas; office space; office equipment;
restroom; and mechanical rooms.
3

In addition to the licensed Shelter Program. The building includes Prevention/Outreach
Services.
B. Program Description
Alternatives for Girls Transition to Independent Living Program (TIL) serves young
women between the ages of 16 to 20 who are homeless or at immediate risk for being
homeless. Program participants may include both homeless young women who are
single and homeless young women with children ages newborn to five. Program
participants learn life skills and utilization of resources in the community. Participants in
the program can reside in the community or live in the residential facility.
The TIL Crisis Shelter can house up to 35 young women and 10 children. The Shelter
Stay is short term and is followed by long-term support through ongoing case
management services. Residents who have young children are responsible for the care
and supervision of their children. A resident may not leave the premises while her child
is in the building.
The staff to resident ratio is 1: 8. Staff includes a Program Director and supervisory,
social service workers, and direct service staff to meet rule requirements.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
None. An onsite inspection and review of the policies and procedures demonstrated full
compliance.
RECOMMENDATION
I recommend issuance of an Original Provisional License to this child caring
institution, private.
